snippet: The disproportionate power enjoyed in the Senate by small states is playing a growing role in the political dynamic on issues as varied as gun control, immigration and campaign finance.
abstract: Disproportionate power enjoyed in Senate by small states, many of which are rural, conservative and Republican-controlled, is playing growing role in political dynamic on issues as varied as gun control, immigration and campaign finance; in response, lawyers, lawmakers and watchdog groups have begun pushing for change, seeking to curb small-states' advantage in Senate rules (Series: Democracy Tested).

byline.contributor: Amanda Cox and Derek Willis contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: The disproportionate power enjoyed in the Senate by small states is playing a growing role in the political dynamic on issues as varied as gun control, immigration and campaign finance.

headline.seo: Senate Gives Small States Power Beyond Their Size
headline.main: Smaller States Find Outsize Clout Growing in Senate
headline.print_headline: Smaller States Find Outsize Clout Growing in Senate
